Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2014 08:18AM Colleen_2 wrote: Waiting for results is the hardest part.  I found reading and doing housework very helpful.  They kept my mind from wandering and kept me busy. Try and find something that you enjoy that will keep your mind busy.  I know it's not easy and your mind will wander.  Try not to do anymore research until you get your results.  Please know you have lots of people here who have gone through and are going through the waiting game so please feel free to ask questions or vent.  Good luck and keep us posted.  Hugs.

Posts.Title: What can I expect with a Axillary Core Needle Biopsy? julz4 Beesie

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2013 09:52AM Colleen_2 wrote: Good luck tomorrow.  I have found that biopsy for me to be very easy.  The needle for the freezing hurts but that doesn't last long and then I didn't feel anything after that.  I found the sound of them taking the samples (sounds like a staple gun) made me jump at first but it was fine.  As for the recovery after, I didn't have any pain but I was very careful not to lift anything for the 24 hours that they tell you or do anything strenuous and I was good.  That was my experience.  I hope yours if pain free as well.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 10:26AM Colleen_2 wrote: Sorry to hear you are going through this.  I know it's not easy but try to keep busy and not worry.  I have been a regular patient lately at our breast cancer centre and see the surgeon regularly as I have had 4 biopsies.  3 of them have come back B9, still waiting on results for the 4th.  What you are going through is the proper protocal.  I know it doesn't make it any easier for you but I hope it makes you feel better that you are not alone in this.  Keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Results coming today NSwrites NSwrites

Posts.Content: Colleen_2 wrote: I feel like I am starting on the same roller coaster as last year.  After many mammograms, ultra sounds, MRI and 6 biopsies, I had a bit of a break.  Now, last Tues. I had my MRI and mammogram, was called back in Friday for more enhanced imaging and received a call from the hospital that I have to have a stereotactic biopsy this Friday.  I will do this one but I have to think, is it time for me to seriously start thinking about having a double mastectomy.  I have a very strong family history and with the ADH diagnoses last year, I don't know how many more biopsies I want to go through.  Also, of course, the anxiety has come back.  It was so nice to have that break from all of the testing and I thought after everything I had last year, that I could get through anything fine, but I guess the axiety has a mind of its own.  Do I just keep getting biopsies?  I know none of you can answer that.  I have to decide for myself.  If any of you have been in this position, is there anything out there that helped you make a decision?  Hugs to everyone. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Decisions Colleen_2 Colleen_2

Posts.Content: Colleen_2 wrote: Last Thurs. I had 2 excisional biopsies.  Prior to the surgery I had a mamo wire insertion on my right breast and an ultra sound wire insertion on my left breast.  During the ultra sound insertion, the radiologist had a difficult time getting the wire in.  He had to keep jamming it and he apologized on being so rough and said that he was having a difficult time getting the wire where he needed it because whatever he had to go through was so "hard".  I have been trying not to think about it but every now and then I worry about it.  This is also the area where I had my first core needle biopsy so I was wondering if maybe it's scar tissue.  Can scar tissue be "hard" for the wire to get through? I guess I just worry because I have a lot of cysts but have never had anything hard.  I don't get my results until Aug. 12th so I was just hoping for someone to tell me that not all hard areas are cancer, that there are other things that can make it difficult for him to get through.  Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.  Hugs to everyone. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: May 2, 2014 04:01PM Colleen_2 wrote: Does anyone else have a hard time scheduling their MRI?  I don't know if it is just my hospital or if this is normal practice.  My surgeon wanted me to have my MRI in April so they scheduled me for April 1st.  I went, got all prepped and ready to go.  I had been there an hour and when they came (I thought to take me to get my IV) they said they had to cancel.  They said my MRI had to be 7-15 days after the start of my last period and I was there on day 16. 1 day! The problem is that I am not on any regular cycle so to try and schedule to make sure it is in that time frame is going to be next to impossible.  They didn't have any openings in May with what we guessed could be the right time of the month so they booked me in for June 24th.  Here's hoping that ends up falling in the right time frame because I am not comfortable waiting any longer to get this done.  Back in August when the surgoen told me I had ADH, she wanted me to do some thinking about a double mastectomy and we would use these results to see if I should do it sooner or could wait until the next MRI.  Now it's going to be almost 10 months since I last saw her and had any tests done so I am getting anxious again about leaving things this long.  I'm just curious as to whether everyone else has to have their MRI's scheduled aroung their cycle or if this is just the way they do things here.
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2013 02:31AM Colleen_2 wrote: I have atypical ductal hyperplasia and it just means I will be tested more frequently as it means you are at a higher risk for developing breast cancer.  I am also in Ontario just east of Toronto.  My mother just had a mastectomy about 6 months ago by a general surgeon here and she was fabulous so that's who I have been seeing as well. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Questions about The Testing Process chen_oscar Colleen_2

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2013 08:59AM Colleen_2 wrote: I was just given the ADH diagnosis this week and medication was never discussed.  We have talked about mastectomies though because I have a very strong family history of breast cancer.  She told me I will have an MRI in about 6-8 months and we can decide after that.  I don't feel comfortable just leaving it for that long but I do trust her.  I guess I am just so used to all of the tests and biopsies over the last few months that it will be strange not doing anything for that long. Hugs to everyone.

Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2017 03:44PM Colleen_2 wrote: Sayheysam - Sorry you have to deal with all of this at such a young age. I was diagnosed with ADH about 4 years ago. I was just going for testing every 6 months for a while to keep an eye on things and then they were moved to once a year. After a discussion with an aunt who is stage 4, she has me worried about just having tests once a year given our family history. I have scheduled an appointment with my surgeon (also my mom's surgeon for her BC) on Jan. 3 to have a discussion about whether I should just go ahead with the surgery. When I was diagnosed with ADH she recommended I have surgery at that time but supported my decision to just keep an eye on things. Now I am worried that maybe I'm just playing with fire by waiting. We will see what she says. Good luck with your appointment and let us know how you make out. I know this is all very stressful. Gentle hugs to you.
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22
